trans-unit.source: Creates a system-defined modeless Find dialog box to search for text in a document

seg-source.mrk: Creates a system-defined modeless Find dialog box to search for text in a document

target.mrk: Creates a system-defined modeless Find dialog box to search for text in a document

trans-unit.source: A handle to the window that owns the dialog box. The window procedure of the specified window receives FINDMSGSTRING messages from the dialog box. This parameter can be any valid window handle, but it must not be 0.

seg-source.mrk: A handle to the window that owns the dialog box.
The window procedure of the specified window receives FINDMSGSTRING messages from the dialog box.
This parameter can be any valid window handle, but it must not be 0.

target.mrk: A handle to the window that owns the dialog box.
The window procedure of the specified window receives FINDMSGSTRING messages from the dialog box.
This parameter can be any valid window handle, but it must not be 0.

trans-unit.source: [optional] The search string that is displayed when you initialize the dialog box.

seg-source.mrk: The search string that is displayed when you initialize the dialog box.

target.mrk: The search string that is displayed when you initialize the dialog box.

trans-unit.source: [optional] A set of bit flags that used to initialize the dialog box.

seg-source.mrk: A set of bit flags that used to initialize the dialog box.

target.mrk: A set of bit flags that used to initialize the dialog box.

trans-unit.source: The dialog box sets these flags when it sends the FINDMSGSTRING registered message to indicate the user's input.

seg-source.mrk: The dialog box sets these flags when it sends the FINDMSGSTRING registered message to indicate the user's input.

target.mrk: The dialog box sets these flags when it sends the FINDMSGSTRING registered message to indicate the user's input.

trans-unit.source: This parameter can be one or more of the following values.

seg-source.mrk: This parameter can be one or more of the following values.

target.mrk: This parameter can be one or more of the following values.

trans-unit.source: [optional] Pointer to an hook procedure that can process messages intended for the dialog box.

seg-source.mrk: Pointer to an hook procedure that can process messages intended for the dialog box.

target.mrk: Pointer to an hook procedure that can process messages intended for the dialog box.

trans-unit.source: This parameter is ignored unless the $FR_ENABLEHOOK flag is not set.

seg-source.mrk: This parameter is ignored unless the $FR_ENABLEHOOK flag is not set.

target.mrk: This parameter is ignored unless the $FR_ENABLEHOOK flag is not set.

trans-unit.source: [optional] Application-defined data that the system passes to the hook procedure.

seg-source.mrk: Application-defined data that the system passes to the hook procedure.

target.mrk: Application-defined data that the system passes to the hook procedure.

trans-unit.source: The window handle to the dialog box.

seg-source.mrk: The window handle to the dialog box.

target.mrk: The window handle to the dialog box.

trans-unit.source: 0 and sets the @error flag to non-zero, @extended flag may contain the dialog box error code.

seg-source.mrk: 0 and sets the @error flag to non-zero, @extended flag may contain the dialog box error code.

target.mrk: 0 and sets the @error flag to non-zero, @extended flag may contain the dialog box error code.

trans-unit.source: The _WinAPI_FindTextDlg() does not perform a search operation. Instead, the dialog box sends FINDMSGSTRING registered messages to the window procedure of the owner window of the dialog box.

seg-source.mrk: The _WinAPI_FindTextDlg() does not perform a search operation.
Instead, the dialog box sends FINDMSGSTRING registered messages to the window procedure of the owner window of the dialog box.

target.mrk: The _WinAPI_FindTextDlg() does not perform a search operation.
Instead, the dialog box sends FINDMSGSTRING registered messages to the window procedure of the owner window of the dialog box.

trans-unit.source: Before calling _WinAPI_FindTextDlg(), you must call the _WinAPI_RegisterWindowMessage() function to get the identifier for the FINDMSGSTRING message. The dialog box procedure uses this identifier to send messages when the user clicks the "Find Next" button, or when the dialog box is closing. The "lParam" parameter of the FINDMSGSTRING message contains a pointer to a $tagFINDREPLACE structure. The "Flags" member of this structure indicates the event that caused the message. Other members of the structure indicate the user's input.

seg-source.mrk: Before calling _WinAPI_FindTextDlg(), you must call the _WinAPI_RegisterWindowMessage() function to get the identifier for the FINDMSGSTRING message.
The dialog box procedure uses this identifier to send messages when the user clicks the "Find Next" button, or when the dialog box is closing.
The "lParam" parameter of the FINDMSGSTRING message contains a pointer to a $tagFINDREPLACE structure.
The "Flags" member of this structure indicates the event that caused the message.
Other members of the structure indicate the user's input.

target.mrk: Before calling _WinAPI_FindTextDlg(), you must call the _WinAPI_RegisterWindowMessage() function to get the identifier for the FINDMSGSTRING message.
The dialog box procedure uses this identifier to send messages when the user clicks the "Find Next" button, or when the dialog box is closing.
The "lParam" parameter of the FINDMSGSTRING message contains a pointer to a $tagFINDREPLACE structure.
The "Flags" member of this structure indicates the event that caused the message.
Other members of the structure indicate the user's input.

trans-unit.source: The _WinAPI_FindTextDlg() uses an internal buffer to hold the string that the user typed in the "Find What" edit controls. You can increase the size of this buffer by using the _WinAPI_SetFRBuffer() function. In addition to free the memory allocated for the internal buffer, you must call the _WinAPI_FlushFRBuffer() in response to the FINDMSGSTRING message with $FR_DIALOGTERM flag set.

seg-source.mrk: The _WinAPI_FindTextDlg() uses an internal buffer to hold the string that the user typed in the "Find What" edit controls.
You can increase the size of this buffer by using the _WinAPI_SetFRBuffer() function.
In addition to free the memory allocated for the internal buffer, you must call the _WinAPI_FlushFRBuffer() in response to the FINDMSGSTRING message with $FR_DIALOGTERM flag set.

target.mrk: The _WinAPI_FindTextDlg() uses an internal buffer to hold the string that the user typed in the "Find What" edit controls.
You can increase the size of this buffer by using the _WinAPI_SetFRBuffer() function.
In addition to free the memory allocated for the internal buffer, you must call the _WinAPI_FlushFRBuffer() in response to the FINDMSGSTRING message with $FR_DIALOGTERM flag set.

trans-unit.source: AutoIt v3 is a freeware BASIC-like scripting language designed for automating the Windows GUI and general scripting. It uses a combination of simulated keystrokes, mouse movement and window/control manipulation in order to automate tasks in a way not possible or reliable with other languages (e.g. VBScript and SendKeys). AutoIt is also very small, self-contained and will run on all versions of Windows out-of-the-box with no annoying "runtimes" required!

seg-source.mrk: AutoIt v3 is a freeware BASIC-like scripting language designed for automating the Windows GUI and general scripting.

It uses a combination of simulated keystrokes, mouse movement and window/control manipulation in order to automate tasks in a way not possible or reliable with other languages (e.g.
AutoIt is also very small, self-contained and will run on all versions of Windows out-of-the-box with no annoying "runtimes" required!

trans-unit.source: AutoIt was initially designed for PC "roll out" situations to reliably automate and configure thousands of PCs. Over time it has become a powerful language that supports complex expressions, user functions, loops and everything else that veteran scripters would expect.

seg-source.mrk: AutoIt was initially designed for PC "roll out" situations to reliably automate and configure thousands of PCs.
Over time it has become a powerful language that supports complex expressions, user functions, loops and everything else that veteran scripters would expect.

Over time it has become a powerful language that supports complex expressions, user functions, loops and everything else that veteran scripters would expect.
